rss.title: Gossip - What is it?
rss.subtitle: Did you see what that girl was wearing?

subtitle_detail.value: Did you see what that girl was wearing?

transcription.full_transcript: Welcome to Catholic Stuff You Should Know, a J-10 initiative. Hey, and welcome to the podcast, Catholic Duckish You Know. This is Joe Doman, and I'm joined today because the last two podcasts, it seems, after a number of inappropriate comments made, we decided to kick Father John Kneppel off the podcast. He just wasn't cutting it, so now my new partner in crime. Nathan Goebel. That's right. Welcome. Thank you very much. Actually, I'm just kidding. No, no kicking off of anybody off the podcast. So we're doing this rotating system where we have Nathan on, myself, John, Father Peter, Father John. And Nathan is always accompanied by a babysitter. A good conscience. Our lady of good counsel. That's right. So yeah, actually I wanted to start this podcast off. Usually we do emails at the end, right? Okay. But... I thought this was appropriate because this is an email regarding the Discernment of Spirits podcast, which I think you and Father John did maybe a month ago or two months ago. But I thought it was worth reading. So this is from Mike in Australia. Mike in Australia. It's kind of cool knowing we have listeners in Australia, I think. After the last podcast, I would recommend not doing it in an Australian accent. highly. So this is what Mike says. He says, congratulations on your ordination, Father John. I listened to the podcast on discernment of spirits and found it very helpful and insightful. He talks about he's going to download Ignatius'spiritual exercises. Great stuff. So this is the meaty stuff here. He says, I know that we are from different cultures. I'm from Australia. and some things you would find offensive, I would not have a problem with, and vice versa. So to us Aussies, when you're angry with something or someone, to use the term P, this is what he types, P dot dot dot st. It rhymes with hissed. Off, hissed off, is offensive, and as a good Catholic boy, constant use would warrant a trip to the confessional in Australia. So I don't know if this was you or Father John, but I figured we were just... throw this warning out there so yeah he makes a few suggestions he says uh we would more use terms such as cranky uh lower than the cut lower than a cut snake or solo you can play handball against the gutter those are the phrases he would use so instead of saying he was ticked off or so he'd say i'm i'm i'm feeling lower than a cut snake so i'm just giving you some more material you know when you're trying to express some feeling that's true A range of motion and dexterity with the lingual muscle. Wonderful. Even though your toilets flush backwards. I appreciate your comment, said viewer. Mike. Mike, yes. Said. That's wonderful. So Nathan, that being said, what are we talking about today? Strangely enough, I want to relate to our listener land that after the last podcast, I decided to revisit the scriptures, and I came across James, Letter to James. And I've been really pondering what are important scriptures to put on your holy card. You know, you want to have something that, I mean, Holy Card is something that you draft when you get ordained to whatever ministry. And it has some pious saying on it, and people put it in books that they, you know, dig out later whenever you become bishop or die or something. So I was reading St. James, and in St. James, he writes, I believe it's in chapter four. He says, the tongue is a fire. and I was like so excited because I thought, yeah, the tongue is a fire, and like it has the power to do amazing things and set people aflame, and Christ even says, I came not to bring, um, Peace upon the earth, but the sword and how I wish it was already blazing. Yada, yada, yada. If you read on from that, he says the tongue is a fire and all it does is spew out wickedness. And if only you could control your tongue, you would be able to control your entire body. But you who are unable to control your tongue are like wild horses and everything. And I was duly chastised. You're a stallion, man. I'm a stallion that needs a bridle bit. So. I want to talk today about sins against, well, yeah, sins of speech. So it kind of maneuvers in between both of those, John De Palma's seal of confession. But this is more for just us regular good Christian folk that are trying to live the Catholic life. And we talked about the seal of confession. So the priest should not reveal certain. secrets, sins, faults about his penitence to other people. In as much, we have the same responsibility. So today we're talking about sins against justice and charity, namely the sins of detraction, slander, calumny. Maybe we'll get into libel, but I don't know how many of our listeners are affected by that. Libel. Yes. Interesting. Which one do you want to start with? I'm interested in libel, but I know you don't even want to get into that first. So let's just start at the beginning. Liable. Why not? Okay. So liable. Okay. So, well, yeah, I should just take your advice all of your time. Okay. So let's start with, let's start with detraction. I think that's, I think that, well, yes. No, this is good stuff. Detraction. Let's start with detraction. I think this one is, uh. a common one that we fall into. It's important that there really is no sin of... There's an umbrella, like you were saying, we were talking about this before, of gossip. But to say the sin of gossip... covers such a multitude of different things that it's difficult to label which one exactly we're talking about. So you've got a gossip and there's a lot of sins underneath the umbrella that qualify. Exactly. You go to that section of your sinful life and you're going to have a whole host of different instances in which you can kind of classify gossip. Maybe whenever you go to confession, you're already saying, I've gossiped about somebody. So what do you understand gossip as? talking about somebody behind their back in a way that is not charitable. Okay. That's an on-the-spot definition. That's pretty good. I actually don't have a definition in front of me because gossip is neither in the catechism nor in Thomas'Summa. He talks about gossipy things, but gossip came much later in terms of— I wonder, does Thomas gossip in the Summa? uh he talks smack about peter lombard a couple times but um always in charity always that's good enough um so okay so detraction so under the umbrella under the category of gossip we have detraction detraction is defined as well i should probably read the definition um detraction is this is from the summa or no i lied this is from catholic encyclopedia detraction is the unjust damaging of another's good name By the revelation of some fault or crime of which that other is really guilty or at any rate is serious believed to be guilty by the defamer. So essentially, you're telling truthful things about a person to a listener, whether it's many people. You're in the confession line and you're going to talk about somebody that just went into the confessional. You're at the Starbucks and you see somebody that you saw. earlier in the week at Murphy's Mug Night, having a few libations. So what could be so wrong in that? So it's basically just saying this person has some sort of fault, and I'm not making this up, and I'm just speaking about it. Yeah, what's wrong with that? What's wrong about telling truthful things about people? I mean, you're supposed to tell the truth, right? Truth. truth is truth i'm all about it truth himself speaks truly or there's nothing true so i mean your parents always taught you to tell the truth somebody says to you oh um you know what do you know about tommy and say you saw tommy getting blistered at you know the the local drinking establishment is it necessary that you that you tell you know well tommy is Tommy's a teetotaler. Start talking about his drinking problems. Yeah. And the interaction. So that's detraction. That's detraction. So it's interesting. Thomas talks about detraction in the sense that he says that reviling someone. reviling someone is like saying something true in front of a whole group of people. So say, you know, you're out, you're out of the bar, Tommy comes, he wants to have a drink, and then you just kind of blurt out in front of everybody. Oh, Tommy, I saw you get drunk the other day. Detraction is done behind someone's back, so that was a good definition, but you're saying truthful things about them. What you've done is you've also ruined their good name, so in both instances, you've done that, but in this situation, whereas the first one is considered violence, in a way, violence by robbery, So like you break into somebody's house, you steal what is rightfully theirs, namely Tommy's good name. Right. And whereas detraction is defined as theft. So you do it in secret. You kind of let yourself in. You know the password or something. Friend asks you something about them. You have this in your back pocket, but you don't have to share it. But instead of, you know, a dull milk toast soda cracker, you have a delightful tidbit, which is... Tammy apparently drinks black Russians frequently. Your analogy totally just broke down for me. Really? I don't understand it. I mean, I get the point about him breaking into the house, but about him, like, taking cookies or... black Russians. Oh, so, um, so you knew that Tommy was a drunkard. You knew you, you saw Tommy get drunk the other day. And therefore when somebody asks you, oh, you know, yeah, I met him. I ran into this guy, Tommy. He's a fairly, fairly all right fellow. So there's another three ways that you can distinguish this. Here's what one of the catechisms says. Revilement. Revilement. Yeah. They're not doing it in front of you. So if they were doing it in front of you, you could defend yourself. But in this situation, now all of a sudden, everyone's going around saying, oh man, Tommy's a cheater. He's a drunk. I hear he picks his nose. I mean, there's like everything. and it all piles up and there's nothing you can do about it. So can you see how they're different? Yeah, they're definitely, I mean, so... Just to draw the main distinction, detraction, you're saying something true, but you're destroying someone's reputation, which is an act against charity. Right. Slander, you're destroying someone's reputation, which is an act against charity, by saying something that's false, which is even worse in a way. Because, I mean, they're both wrong. Yes. But that's the difference. Slander, you're making up stuff and destroying their reputation. Detraction, you're just... saying what people don't need to know. summarization.results: The discussion focuses on the importance of controlling speech to avoid sins like detraction, slander, and calumny, which can harm others' reputations. It distinguishes between revealing true but unnecessary information (detraction), spreading false information (slander), and making false accusations (calumny). The conversation emphasizes the significance of preserving one's good name, maintaining confidences, and refraining from gossip to uphold trust and honor within a community.
